title: Syrian Ex-Officer Is Convicted in First Trial of Assad Regime Torture
sub_head: German court verdict could help pave the way for other convictions of Syrian officials around the world
body:
BERLIN—A German court secured the world’s first conviction of a former Syrian official in relation to state-sanctioned torture in what lawyers and human-rights groups hailed as a breakthrough in the effort to bring the regime to account.
The court Wednesday found Eyad al-Gharib, a 44-year-old former Syrian regime officer, guilty of aiding and abetting crimes against humanity, sentencing him to 4½ years in prison for helping to suppress opposition activity after the 2011 antigovernment uprising against the regime of President Bashar al-Assad.
While Mr. Gharib’s crimes took place in Syria, prosecutors invoked the principle of universal jurisdiction, which allows the prosecution of war crimes regardless of where they are committed.
“Germany has opened the road to justice for Syrians,” said Joumana Seif, Syrian human-rights lawyer and research fellow at the European Center for Constitutional and Human Rights, which is representing some of the former detainees who are plaintiffs in the case.
“This is the first time that Assad’s crimes are being presented in front of a court,” she said.
